reviewText:
Fran Bow is the story of the game's titular little girl who, at the start of the game, experiences the death of her parents and is stuffed away into a mental institution. Fran is determined to get out of the loony bin and meet up with her cat, Mr. Midnight, who she is convinced will help guide her and form a new life with her beloved Aunt Grace. However, some form of shadowy demon warns her to stay in the mad house, for if she leaves he will hunt her down, and do worse things than she could ever imagine. The game's got clever writing, interesting characters (with Fran Bow's childish yet twisted thought-process and approach to things stealing the show), mixed with interesting imagery, thoughtful but not entirely too difficult puzzles, a gripping story with themes of psychological horror, satanism, and cult behaviors, the twistedness of children, and real horror ranging from pedophilia to the history of mental care.

Fairly early in the game you get a jar of pills, which lets you switch at anytime between the 'real' world, and a twisted gorey world full of shadow monsters. Sometimes switching between these worlds provides interesting symbolism and visual imagery, but at other moments it can be crucial to progress. As the game goes on, it becomes questionable if this other world is truly just a hallucination, as things done in one world seem to effect the other.

Depending on how much you take to exploring and getting through puzzles, I'd estimate the game at around 7-12 hours long. They switch up locales and some gameplay stuff enough to keep things interesting, between the 5 chapters you visit 7 different 'main' locales, and four of those locations have two different versions of the location to travel between (and the fifth one has four different versions of itself). In-between main locations, there are often some optional mini-games, which you can skip if you wish but I found most to be a joy. Minor spoiler, but my personal favorite of the mini-games being a nicely timed Frogger reference,

Music is worth mentioning, it is very stylistic with some tracks sticking out, with some melodic tones and synth sounds mixed in. There's no voice acting, but the ambiance sounds are good and captivating. Presentation also gets high marks for some nice animation, visual flair, detail, and some stylization in certain scenes (like the storybook maze scene).

High recommendation if you want a twisted point'n'click. The game isn't scare-your-pants-off terrifying, but there were a few scenes that made me jump, a few kind of chilling and disturbing moments, a sort of grotesque fairy tale feel that resonates most of the game. While reflecting I think I might like the first half of the game more than the second half, it's a fairly paced title worth playing through to the end, and can be an absolutely engrossing experience. Lead by interesting characters is a bit less interesting but still engaging story, excellent writing, great presentation style and audio, and capturing the perfect tone of a twisted little girl's mind in a just as, if not more, twisted horrific world. Fran Bow will most certainly become one of the greats in horror point'n'clicks, it's not perfect and without saying too much, while not an abrupt ending it kind of feels like a sequel hook and a bit anti-climatic, and I feel the middle sections of the game was a bit too long and disjointed from the rest of the title that there was a bit of a slump after the segment to get back into the game's main narrative and atmosphere... But it is entirely worth playing and is a macabre little girl's journey that's twist, turns, and cross-world traveling is more than worth experiencing.

reviewText:
(Disclaimer:  I was a volunteer English proof reader for this game for the last four months of its development.  I also contributed as a backer to the Indiegogo campaign which funded some of the development of this game.)

I absolutely adore this game.  If you like point and click adventure games,  please give this one a whirl.  And if you've never tried a point and click adventure game, I think this one will make you love them forever.

The art is gorgeous, the animations are beautiful to look at, the sound effects are plentiful and well designed, and the ever changing music adds so much to the ambiance of the game.  But above all, the story of the game is so detailed and rich and keeps you interested to see what happens next.  If you're like me, when you finish the game, you'll definitely wish the story wasn't over.

Many people complain about puzzles in adventure games being illogical and that it's difficult to figure out what the game developer had in mind for a solution.  Well, the puzzles in Fran Bow are very logical, the items needed to solve the puzzle are always within a screen or two of where they are used to solve the puzzle, and solving the puzzles always gives the player a good sense of satisfaction when they are completed.  Solving puzzles without the need for a walkthrough is one indication that a game is well designed, and, in my opinion, this game meets that test--I think the puzzles can be solved by an observant player without a walkthrough.

This game has two major game mechanics which are truly original and inspired designs of the developers.  Both make the game a joy to play and allow the player to see even more of the delicious art design of the single artist who designed and single-handedly drew all the art and animations in the game.  There are so many little details built into the game, involving art, animation, and programming--the footprints made in the snow, which are made as the characters walks over freshly fallen snow, which then fill in as the snow continues to fall, with the sound of crunching snow as the character walks, for example--that absolutely show the level of detail and love the two indie developers of Fran Bow put into the game, all to make the story feel so very real for the player.

I believe that if you play this game, you will not be disappointed.  You will fall in love with the characters in the story, you'll root for the success of the main character, cheer for her, feel both happy at times, and sad at times for her, and boo and hiss at those characters who appear to be against her.  I both laughed and cried while playing this game, and I believe that you will too when you play.

It's clear to me that this is a very special game that makes you think about the things said in the game.  The two-person development team poured much love, time, and hard work into the game.  You will likely want to play the game more than once in order to absorb all the story told in it--it is that intracate.  The result is a wonderful story that you will remember for a long time, and Fran Bow just may become your favorite adventure game, like it is for me.  I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Fran Bow is a labour of love --- down to every detail you can feel the creativity that went into producing this game.

It is a point-and-click, story and text- based game with some choice and several unique mini art games and puzzles that break the gameplay up to make things fun and interesting on your journey into Fran's world. A love of gamemaking, puzzles and beautiful concept art is everywhere in the landscape of Fran Bow. No screenshots are allowed in this game because so many of the visuals hold clues to the story and are unforgettable scenes you will never find in any other game.

This game defies genre, it starts off as doll-core horror in a mental asylum for children and then becomes fantastical, magical, mythology- inspired; reminiscent of some of the old Sierra adventure games like King's Quest 6, except the mythology is completely invented by Fran Bow.

The game deals with the stigma of mental illness in children and attempts to give the player the experience of a child's curious mind marred by delusions and trauma. The game itself is therapuetic for the imagination to play and it is easy to become immersed in the mythology of Fran's mind.

This game will give you nightmares; but if you perservere through the story, it will reward you in spades. It speaks true to Winston Churchill's famous quote: If you are going through hell; keep going."

The only criticism I have is Fran's purse inventory made it a bit awkward to access items and try them at times - maybe a bar at the top to access items or a drag feature for combining items would have made it easier. But otherwise
date: I wish there were more games like this.\nGood job Kill Monday and kudos to the artist here for beautiful storyboarding and concept art.\n10/10 would play again."

reviewText:
This has to be one of the best point and click games in the past few years. Sure, Daedalic pulled out quite a few good ones, but not as invigorating and enticing as this one.

The description of this game is as far as spoilers should go when you're interested in this game. If you're not convinced, go play the demo.

The atmosphere, asthetic, music and characteristics of this game are absolutely gorgeous. Yes, there's some cheesy dialogue that made me roll my eyes, but when taking it from the perspective that this game is going for, it's certainly well in place. The protagonist isn't a 'know it all badass' or 'hopelessly confused person' like in most games. Instead, it's just an innocent girl that kind of stays innocent throughout the game.
There are many, many 'oh my, what the hell' moments throughout the game, excluding the very disturbing images after taking the pills. Even without those, it's still gritty and disturbing.

The journey is filled with (unpleasant) surprises, which hadn't taken an impact on me since playing Darkseed or Tormented. Some of the story is vague, but there are many clues to figure it out.

The downside is that 'some' of the puzzles are just plain annoying or don't make sense at all. For me, personally, there was a math 'puzzle' that didn't make sense. Or I had to interact an item in my inventory with a character, which could have easilly solved by just interacting with that character, like the rest of the game functioned before this particular 'puzzle'.
The UI is a bit clunky as well and doesn't respond as something like monkey island or the rather clunky Machinarium, which is strange, considering that the latter is a flash game. The UI in this game just doesn't respond at times.

Despite these slight flaws, I want to thank the developers for this amazing game and hope that they can make more of these masterpieces.

Bottom line: If you're a point 'n click adventurer... Go get this game. like some horror and aren't too afraid of the dark? Then this game is worth every cent.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Thought provoking!

The subject of psychology has always been interesting to me. Mental disorder, insanity, truth, reality and consciousness are all things this game reflects on.

You play as a little girl that goes through a significant trauma having lost her parents and ends up being treated in a slightly dodgy mental institution. You go through any means possible to escape the asylum, be reunited with your best (and only) friend, your beloved cat, Mr. Midnight and get back home. The journey is full of turns and oddities that will further add to the question of Fran’s mental state.

The story is intriguing to follow and always begs the question of what is going on. Even when you find answers, there was always (at least for me) an underlining curiosity over what was real and which side was true.

Insanity tends to bring distrust, whether the person is sane or not, given the label of “Insane” by someone “Sane” will always lead to uncertainty about the person. You fight with Fran to keep her certainty and sanity against the people who are trying to keep her locked up.

I really enjoyed this game. The art style and use of colour is great at getting across the right emotions. Oppressive scenes are dark and cold, safe and comfortable scenes are bright and open. The music also adds drama to the game in the right places and helps to set in those emotions.

There is no voice acting, although with this game I thought that it kind of fit in that way.

There is a fun mechanic which lets you switch the scene between the every day reality, to the reality Fran sees when she takes her medication. It opens up new possibilities for point and click puzzle solving and makes the game that tad bit more interesting and eerie. Effectively showing two sides to every situation.

The transitioning between chapters is a good way to break up a fairly lengthy game and essentially “skip” the unnecessary bits to play (for example, the travel to where the next chapter is set).

I found that the game flowed well, especially for a point and click. I usually get stuck fairly quickly in these genre of games but there was only a few times I got stuck and even then I think that was because I played until it was late and I was tired. Returning to the game after a break with a fresh mind usually solved the problem pretty quickly.

In terms of 100%ing this game it’s fairly easy. You aren’t likely to get everything on your first play through, but it’s easy enough to do a quick run through again to get any you missed. I played through the game twice in the hours I have put into it if that is any help.

All in all this is a great game, I liked it! I would say it’s a must try for people that like the point and click genre or generally have any interest in mental disorder, psychology or even just thinking about things a little more philosophically.

I just completed this game today. I was originally interested in purchasing this game myself after seeing one of my favourite Youtubers play through the demo. In the video they said the full game release date which happened to be the day before I watched the video, so I decided then that instead of simply watching the let's play, I'd actually play the game through myself - and boy am I glad I did! I love games which have a little 'something' that makes them different, and this game had just that. I really like Fran as a character and I think it's very easy to want to be on her side. Speaking of characters, there are tons of really creative personalities in this game who really keep you interested, change things up and keep you on your toes.

As far as the game itself goes, it was a real pleasurable journey to go on overall (even with all the gore and disturbances!) and I only had one issue with it which was being unable to ''continue'' if you happened to save the game right where the demo left off, but I understand that has been fixed by the time I have written this review which shows how speedy the ones in charge were to fix little mishaps like that, which is always good. Either way it wasn't such as big deal as the opening section did not take too long to repeat.

Fran Bow has a real good story and is certainly a challenge in parts (thank God for the discussion hub here!) but that only added to the experience for me in the sense that it was something that in some instances you really had to think about and get involved with. On the other hand it was equally as good when the answer has been staring you in the face and you finally get it and have that ''Oh, duh!'' moment!

As you can probably tell by how fondly I speak of this game in this review - it's obvious to anyone that I love it. However, one of my only criticisms is that the ending left a little too many loose ends. I appreciate that the game leaves the player to decide what they think about the whole thing as there's nothing more disappointing than when a game gives you a set in stone ending which you're kind of ''eh'' about and leaves a bad feeling over your experience however I would have encouraged just a few of the open-ended questions to come to a definite conclusion. That being said, that may just be the nature of this very game. It's mysterious and nobody really knows what the truth is in the House of Madness. Plus, this is one of those games where I really wouldn't mind discussing ideas with others and coming up with a personal ending that feels right in your own heart which is endearing in its own way as well.

Aside from that I really have nothing bad to say about this game, I love psychological horrors, I love interesting stories and cool characters in video games and Fran Bow ticked all the boxes for me. It instantly reminded me of ''Alice in Wonderland; Madness Returns'' which is a similar game in terms of story / characters that I love dearly so I knew that I wouldn't be going wrong if I bought this game. I do feel that it may be inspired by Alice in Wonderland, especially given the photo of Fran and her friend Alice in chapter 5 inside of her wardrobe. That little reference made me really quite happy, actually. Probably more than it should of. But yeah, although the two games share aspects that I love they're also different enough for each other for both experiences to be refreshing. I mean, I could honestly play the two one after the other and not get the feeling that it was tedious. My heart was in this one, I loved every second of it, well done to the creators! I'll definitely be doing a fan art of this game soon!

reviewText:
It is far harder to kill a phantom than a reality.

As someone who is not fond of horror or point & click games, Fran Bow was a pleasant surprise. From its unsettling atmosphere, to the array of intriguing characters, everything in Fran Bow is clearly a labour of love.

The artstyle is the first thing I fell in love with. It immediately reminded me of the intro sequence to Alice: Madness Returns. The animations are well done, and remain consistent through the entire game. The game uses a lot of gore, but it's not just any gore. It's artistic gore. That's right, the gore in this game is artistic gore. Rather than feeling disgusted, the gore in Fran Bow made me want to take a closer look at the screen out of interest, something no other game except for LISA has compelled me to do.

The music in Fran Bow is well done. Nothing much to say about it, other than it is good enough to be worth purchasing the Original Soundtrack DLC.

Now, the thing that really gripped me: the gameplay. Yes, it's your average point & click in terms of control and inventory. However, one mechanic stood out: the pills. Fran can take pills to see and enter an alternate reality. You may take pills and subdue their effect at any time. The images, objects, and beings you see from taking pills, are often quite quite disturbing, but in a good way. You will need to use the pills to solve puzzles, so they provide more than just interesting imagery. For Legend of Zelda fans, think of it as the Magic Mirror from Link to the Past that allows you to travel to the Dark World.

Now, the question most people wonder: Are there jumpscares? The answer is yes and no. There are sudden popups, such as a character popping from behind a door you are about to enter, or heads falling from a staircase into the room. However, Fran Bow does not use the cheap tactics games such as Five Nights at Freddy's utilize. Nothing pops out at the screen at you. Without spoiling too much, I can confidently say that this game is indeed unsettling and in a way, scary, but the jumpscares" are the lesser of evils this game has to bring.

I usually don't bother writing reviews, but Fran Bow delivers one of the stronger experiences you can get out of a game.

Gameplay-wise, it is a well written point and click adventure with puzzles that are reasonably challenging, but not to the point you will get stuck often. The music and audio work well to set up the atmosphere, and the graphics have a peculiar character and beauty. The puzzles, audio and, especially, the visuals, are good, although they don't reach the heights of modern masterpieces, such as Machinarium. However, one should consider that this game was actually made by two people and it does illustrate what indie game developers can do.

These factors alone would make a good game, but Fran Bow stands out in two ways. First, it introduces a unique mechanic which consists of visiting alternate realities or seasons which are crucial to the puzzle solutions: In one chapter Fran can move through time by controlling the seasons, while in another three chapters she can move between what might be called a waking world and a world of shadows, the latter being a dark and haunting place where a dinning table full of candy can be replaced by mutilated bodies.

Second, and most important, Fran Bow's story and atmosphere is like a slightly more coherent Alice in Wonderland, but darker, scarier, twisted, and occasionally more dreamlike and touching, where the limits between reality and hallucination are blurred. It is set in a surprisingly rich world with five realities, peculiar creatures and places, and even a made up alphabet which you can decipher thanks to an in-game book. It easy to get engulfed in the story and share Fran's fears, sorrows, and hopes.

This is an experience you will remember for a lifetime.

reviewText:
This was an amazing experience, one that will stay with me for a long time.

Gameplay-wise, it mostly follows the basic conventions of a point-and-click adventure with an interesting mechanic which makes two versions of nearly every scene that you often have to switch back and forth between to work out the next step. Interspersed here and there are puzzles and little mini-games that are more action-oriented. (Some of those mini-games are interesting takes on other classic games, for instance Frogger.) Those can present some moderate difficulty for the most part, though in a few places I was making them harder than they should have been because some rule wasn't obvious - for instance, not realizing in an early maze mini-game that I could approach enemies from certain directions more closely than other directions until I'd already restarted the sequences a number of times. That's a good warning going in: try not to overcomplicate some of the puzzles and games when the solution is much simpler. Of the puzzles, there was really only one that I found a little ridiculous (it's shown in one of the screenshots on the store page). In all, it remained fun to play without being boringly easy or stupidly difficult.

It was the elements of the story itself, however, that made it so memorable to me. This isn't the first time I've seen very dark subject matter presented in a manner similar to a children's book, but I'm not sure I've seen it done so well. The character of Fran Bow herself is a big factor in this; her stubborn childish innocence throughout everything that was going on was not only endearing, it helped to lend weight to the darker parts of the story. At no point did I feel like this character was acting in a way inconsistent with how she was first presented. She's a ten year old girl and she seems like a ten year old girl. All of the fantastic settings she finds herself in are well worth the visit and I enjoyed her childish reactions to them. In fact, it's odd how in such a dark game I found myself genuinely smiling at certain points. The plot itself is rich, even if the ending, which I'm still working out how I feel about, goes off in a strange (and possibly not completely satisfying) direction.

In any case, if you enjoy a good adventure game and a good horror story, you'll be doing yourself a disservice if you give this game a skip. Get it. Frankly, I feel I could have paid more for it and gotten my money's worth.

reviewText:
Video playthrough: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLpM8eWCyT1HRWALbs7po4SVB3ZrYEaGt6

This game is absolutely phenominal! A horrific tale presented from the perspective of such a young heroine. The game is a test of courage mixed with a plea to retain innocence.

The artstyle, reminiscent of the 90s TV show Angela Anaconda (yet cleaner, smoother and, of course, gorier) fits in so well with the plot and the point-and-click style. Flashbacks are presented in a noir style, but maintain a modern presentation and flow that holds your attention until you retain control again. Everything works great with tight controls and easily distinguishable objects and backgrounds.

The music and sound effects only serve to enhance the cartoony, yet horrific, images you will have to encounter on your journey. It will serve to sway and move you as you interact with characters springing to life with their own personalities. Although you need to read dialogue, you will easily be able to find each character's voice and relate to them in your own way within a few words.

The gameplay itself, which involves collecting and combining items and solving puzzles, is nothing new, but is absolutely intuitive to the design of this game. You will get stumped at times, but not to the point where you will feel like something is impossible.

Overall, I had a very pleasant experience with this game. The full release truly showcases the real horrific beauty of Fran's tale.

I can't say I didn't enjoy Fran Bow, but as a story based game it leaves a bad taste in my mouth with writing decisions which leave too much room for speculations.

What I enjoyed: It's set in a very well designed world with lots of loveable and relatable characters. It's kind of weird though how the game plays out. It's supposedly a horror game, but it's barely functioning as one. The game incorporates a lot of peaceful and likeable characters and enviroments, which is very rare, but it's not a concept which can't work, and here it kind of does. With this it's easy to make a huge contrast so it's shocking elements have a bigger effect. Using this, the game switches between dark and happy themes a few times to make a world which may as well be Fran's disturbed mind, and it's presented with a gorgeous art style. Also, for the most part the writing is good, but unfortunately when it matters the most they failed to make something interesting.

It's hard to talk about what I don't like about this game without spoiling anything. So for those of you who don't want it to get spoiled, the game's story is written in a way that when you get answers it only raises more questions. And in the end you get so much ♥♥♥♥ thrown at you (trying to explain what exactly happened) that it's not only overwhelming, but feels like a very heedless way to fininsh a game. Everything which happens in the last like 10 minutes is just a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, and I don't mean it in a way that it's completely unlikeable, there were moments which were great and memorable, but outside of that it's really just a rushed way to try and tighten up loose ends, but it just couldn't do that with all of them.

So yeah, it's hard to explain what I didn't like, but all in all it was a pleasant experience.

reviewText:
Fran Bow is a fantastic point and click game with great art,writing and music only thing stopping it form the best of the best is a kinda lackluster ending.

This game blew me away and I never heard of it in fact my wife told me about it numerous times until I bought it for her.
Bored I installed it and played and couldn't stop I just couldn't stop playing this amazing game.

The music is absolutely fantastic and so is the stroy and the mystery surrounding fran.

Puzzles are pretty easy and its very hard to miss items or to pass various screens and having to backtrack to find that item.

Levels are pretty self contained and there are no crazy solutions.

One cool feature are the pills, every time you use them fran jumps into a crazy gory dimension in wich she can pick new items or open doors I thought it was a pretty cool concept and very interesting too.

Lenght wise the game might last you a day or two and there are no reason to replay them except for achievements which some of them are kinda obscure since you can solve a few situations more than one way.

The game has 5 chapters, now I wish I could tell you that all of them are excellent but thats not the case.

Chapter 1 and 2 are fantastic and set a super nice and obscure tone for the game but then chapter 3-4 appear and it just kinda washes all what was done before for a more happy enviroment. It threw me off for sure especially chapter 3 dragged a lot.

Chapter 5 is the final chapter and we get back to the dark mood of the first two chapters but it falls flat at the ending.
The ending is open for interpretation and I wont spoil anything BUT the ending was rushed, waaaaay to rushed waaaay to much into your face new characters are introduced in the last 2 min of the game just to make a point.

I feel the ending and chapter 3 take down what could have been a fantastic adventure.

Should you buy it ? well if you like games like the Cat Lady and dont expect it to be better then absolutly buy it. its a great game with a fantastic soundtrack.

7.5/10

reviewText:
I don't normally post reviews, but I have to say, this game irritated me to no end.
From a gameplay standpoint, there's nothing wrong with it. This is your standard point-and-click adventure, nothing too innovative here. The art is... interesting, but not displeasing. The soundtrack is forgettable but not terrible.
My biggest issue with this game is the story.
Look, this game is about a child with a mental illness. It is obviously supposed to be bizarre and otherworldly. I understand that parts of it may be vague/confusing/strange/gross/etc to help the player see the world through the child's eyes and to  up the horror factor. This becomes a problem however when the bizarre is so overdone that it overshadows the narrative.  The 'this child is crazy' bit is pushed so hard that the story gets lost in there. By the time I got to the 3rd chapter, I had no idea what was happening anymore. The ending is extremely dissatisfying and doesn't resolve or explain anything. The things that are explained are far too complex for this sort of game, so they fall short in helping the player understand... well, anything.
Now, I won't say this was a horrible game. I enjoyed it for the most part, and I don't regret the money I paid for it. However, I will say this: if you're looking for a complete, comprehendable story this is not your game. If you're looking for an art piece or just generally something to creep and gross you out, then buy it.
I, for one, was looking for a story, and as such, cannot recommend it.

reviewText:
Based on all the reviews up here so far I was expecting something a little more impressive.

From the getgo I was put off by the fact that this felt very much like a phone port to me. I know this isn't currently available on any phones but the interface seemed to be designed for a touch screen and the visual quality is extremely lacking in a way where it appears to have been blown up to fit the resolution of a larger screen (which is disappointing because the illustrations are very lovely). I checked if there were any graphics options, but there weren't. You shouldn't have to play something in windowed mode to make it look nice.

Some of the design choices also turned me off a bit. The text font and cursor seem to be an afterthought when compared to how lovely the drawing is. I know this is a nitpicky complaint but it cheapened the experience for me.

Since I only played through the first chapter I can't speak to the full quality of the puzzles as the developers may have thrown in some complications, but for me the swallowing pills to swap back and forth between normal/nightmare mode got dull pretty quick. It was fun to see all the insane imagery but it would have been nice if this function offered something a little more in depth than giving clues to solutions that are really pretty simple to figure out. There was no real gameplay motivation to take the pills other than two points where the two perspectives served to directly influence one another and they were a little obvious to be totally satisfying. But as I said, I only played an hour of the game. The puzzles may get much more complicated but the connect the dots logic in chapter 1 was giving me some nasty flashbacks to Broken Age.

In terms of what I got from the premise of this game: clever in concept but could be handled with more finesse (not talking about the full narrative arc here, just nuances I picked up). The dialogue was definitely so-so. Sometimes I got into the mindset of this being a 10-year-old and sometimes it felt very clunky. Yes these characters aren't mentally all there in a lot of cases, but some of this awkward dialogue can be attributed to the hospital's staff. This iffyness is something I felt in some of the game's imagery as well. Some of it worked super well and some of it stuck out  like reading a weak metaphor in an otherwise thoughtful poem (Dead clowns stuffed in toy chests and heads shafted into a decapitated horse on a wooden pole? KEEP IT COMING FAM THIS STUFF IS TASTY! Pentagrams and grandfather clocks with eyes? ehhhhhhh.........a little forced in terms of meaning")

All of this aside
date: if this game truly seemed to be optimized for pc I would feel a little better about recommending it. As it is now I would say it's possibly worth checking out at a discounted price. NOT SAYING TO AVOID THIS COMPLETELY. I definitely appreciate the effort put into this by such a small team and I would have never written this much about a game I though was flat out bad. It's something way wild to look at and It may just be your thing. Unfortunately in this case there were enough things that irked me to take me out of the experience and felt someone needed to be devil's advocate so they don't feel swindled by the overwhelming positivity (which is what happened to me
recommended: I know I'm an idiot)\n\nTry the demo out before you click purchase."

As someone who works in the field of psychology, Fran Bow struck a chord with me. Despite sporting some of the most imaginatively grotesque and inspired horrific imagery in a videogame in many years, it's a tragic and empathic examination of a mental illness back during a time when caring was in short supply. The game doesn't pull any punches when it comes to why the children are there such as sexual abuse where a hallucination of a shadow creature is seen leaving bloody marks on the child's body. Nearly every single screen in the first few chapters has a messed up hallucinatinatory side, and credit to the artists that despite the gore, it's evocative in macabre beauty.

Much like Neverending Nightmares in the year before which dealt with obsessive compulsive disorder, Fran Bow in dealing with paranoid schizophrenia and dissociated personality disorder has reality and fantasy mixing enough that it's hard to make out what exactly is going on. There is an element of dark humour as Fran herself is a strange character who reacts to intense imagery with child-like innocence such as when ghouls are holding her disembodied head outside the window, she just wants them to give her head back. Maybe that element of lightness is part of her denial and also for the game to differentiate itself from grimdark horror games, rather more in line with American McGee's Alice games.

It's a pure point-and-click adventure that requires looking at items, combining them with each other, in addition to having lots of keys and locks. Sometimes I wish there was a way to find out what the objective was when I came back to this game after a few days. There's a lot of variety in the environments and backgrounds especially in the last couple of chapters when multiple realities keep popping up. All this trouble just to find a cat! Aside from the Alice videogames, there are very few psychological horror games that maintain this kind of darkly humorous yet intense tone so if any of this intrigues you, check it out.

I am one of the most forgiving critics I can think of. Knowing how difficult game development is, I am quite willing to admire what a game does right over complaining of what it does wrong. As long as the developers have put evident enthusiasm and heart into the title—think Deadly Premonition or Sanitarium for instance—I find it much more gratifying to exercise a little patience and sift the gold out of the muck.

In the growing category of deeply personal indie games, though, I find this practice increasingly difficult. See, in creating a deeply personal game developers tend to make the narrative overly metaphorical and obtuse. I encountered this most recently in the RPG Maker phantasmagoria Stray Cat Crossing. Here the metaphors and the vague story took away from the experience, made it more difficult to connect to on an emotional level. As connecting emotionally ought to be one of the key ambitions of these personal indies, making it purposely impenetrable seems a self-defeating design choice.

In short, I am apprehensive when approaching narrative-driven games with an ambiguous plot. Killmonday Game's Fran Bow is certainly one of these. The feelings, as always, are mixed. By and large it is a great game, but whether or not it would be improved by a clearer story is a question that has been at the forefront of my mind since completion.

Fran Bow is the story of the titular character, a young girl who is shipped off to a children's mental asylum after her parents are brutally murdered. And without even getting the chance to say goodbye to her cat! Deeply unhappy, lonely, missing her feline friend and experiencing strange hallucinations from the drugs she is ordered to take, Fran sets out to escape the asylum. From there her journey features—but is not limited to—creepy forest animals, malicious conjoined twin sisters, a charming skeleton man, abominations beyond the ken of humanity and talking root vegetables.

Now, Fran Bow takes an Alice in Wonderland turn after its first chapter. This was jarring to me as a player, I was expecting something much more grounded in reality. Yet I have never been one to let my expectations get in the way of my enjoyment of something, so I went along for the ride.

From the outset, Fran Bow is full of beautiful visuals, ranging from the horrific to the quixotic. The Tim Burton-style art is charming and varied, showcasing a talent as qualified for saccharine-sweet scenes and Silent Hill-tier grotesqueness. Fran Bow is at its heart a visual experience, a sort of interactive storybook with clever puzzles. Certain brief interludes (one a platformer, one a maze and another a Frogger clone) take advantage of claymation—the original presentation style of the never-completed film Fran Bow is based upon—and other art styles. It is all a hodgepodge of settings, themes and styles, both dark and childlike—a sort of smorgasbord for the artist's talents. One genuinely gets the sense of joy in each scene, whether it be pretty or creepy—the joy of an artist making something they want to make.

Yet the problem with these varied settings is this: How do they come together in a plot? Well, I have been building up, the execution doesn't quite give everything the player needs to really experience the story. There are common themes among each location—everywhere you travel is, for instance, located on small islands—but the narrative makes great stretches to achieve continuity. An entire mythology is introduced to explain the greatly disparate nature of each location. The lines between reality and fiction blur.

While it does make an acceptable amount of sense by the end of Fran Bow, the game begins to lose its focus on Fran Bow herself. In crafting all these brilliant worlds, getting lost in their terror and wonder, Fran herself gradually gets pushed into the background. Her story, the story we set out to experience, gets muddled by so many other elements that the game introduces after we first leave the asylum.

In the end, Fran's story becomes deeply ambiguous. What is real and what is fiction? This reality-screwing is a purposeful theme for Killmonday, yet it doesn't quite reach the coherence it needs to be fully fleshed out. Fran Bow perhaps bites off more than it can chew—introducing many wonderful elements but never combining them satisfactorily. After a few chapters, Fran Bow starts to feel patched together. Her story is a network of psychological horror, children's fantasy, V.C. Andrews and surrealism.

I don't believe that Fran Bow is one of those games who tells an ambiguous plot just because the developers couldn't find a way to tell it clearly. No, there was clearly more heartfelt intention behind this title. For that it earns a great deal of respect, for it is rare for a developer to create a game with such a personal and emotionally-charged vision in mind.

The main problem here is that this vision branches in many directions. We've got Fran's character development branch, her connection to her cat branch, the mystery of her parents' murder branch, the What's the deal with these drugs they prescribed to Fran?" branch
date: the mysterious new worlds she visits branch... All of them are good. None of them are given enough attention. By the end the player isn't quite sure which branch we've finally landed on
recommended: or indeed if these branches work together at all."

This will be spoiler-y, but not explicitly so.


First, the good. The game is a solid length and at no point feels rushed. Fran is a genuinely likeable and sympathetic child whose deep affection for her cat is something anyone with a childhood pet can relate to. Wonderful music. It often made me think of Phil Glass and his work on Koyaanisqatsi. Great animations and a very pleasing visual style. One sympathizes with Fran and finds her a pretty believeable character. She is perhaps a little desensetized to the horror she sees and reacts in a surprisingly sanguine manner, but youth and trauma will do that. Quick first line summary:  I really enjoyed this game, and would recommend it with very little hesitation.

Gameplay
It’s a point and click adventure game.  So you gather items from the various screens you can access and you use those items on characters or objects in the area to get access to more screens where you do more of the same.  This is pretty standard fare, so unless you have never played one before you already know how this works.  I will say that the puzzles are very logical for this sort of game, and the few times I got stuck it was entirely because of my own mistakes.

Visual Style
The visual look of the game is delightful.  I loved all the character art, and the locations were convincing and immersive.  If you are turned off by gore and upsetting imagery you might want to give this one a miss.  I found that the cartoony look offset the violence depicted, so it didn’t bother me, but I know I would advise my mother to stick to more light hearted stuff.  I did really like the spookiness of it all, and the odd moment where they decided to depict something particularly grotesque kept me always waiting for what would come next.

Story
Point and click adventure games seem to be the place to go for story these days.  Fran Bow’s story kept me strung along for the entire ride.  I liked what they did with some characters, the surprises they dropped here and there.  There wasn’t really any plot twists or sudden shifts of character that just came out of the blue and left me disbelieving.  Everything could, and was, explained with context and perspective to make sense.  Having said all that, there is one aspect of the story that I would need to say is this games weakest point, and unfortunately that is the ending.  I’m not going to spoil anything specifically, but if you want to experience the game completely blind, you might as well skip the next paragraph.

For the entire game there was one massive looming adversary with infrequent hints of shadow players in the wings.  When the final chapters rolled around that adversary just disappeared and was replaced with new ones at the last minute who were just as quickly bumped off in the most contrived way possible and then the game ended.  Just like that.  After all the build-up, all the hidden hints, all the vague clues to various possible twists and various possible conclusions, and all the uncertainty about how it could possibly work out well in the end, all the loose ends are just gathered up all at once and tied into one big deus ex machina bow.

Final Word
My final word on it echoes my first words.  I do highly recommend this game.  It has a few flaws, but it is an entrant in my library that I’m happy to have there.  It does make me want to check out other things this developer brings to the table.

This is a very fascinating yet horrific game. It takes inspiration from Alice in Wonderland and twists it with horror aspects and gore to paint a terrifyingly beautiful picture. You play as a little girl named Fran Bow, who is trapped in a mental asylum after the brutal death of her parents. Your only goal is to escape and find your pet kitty Mr. Midnight. The question is how to do it... and figuring out the meaning of seeing things no-one else can see. Let's just say you need to take the red pill every once in a while.

The story from what I've gathered after three straight hours of play thus far is fairly simplistic, almost like a children's fairytale... albeit a fairytale definitely made for adults and NOT kids (seriously do NOT buy this game for your kids! Despite its cutesy artstyle there is a ton of disturbing/bloody/gory imagery throughout that can be very frightening.)

Some of my favorite aspects of the game are the little nods to various old school games found within minigames played throughout the point and click tale. There's a maze minigame similar to Pac-Man, a river crossing game that's basically a repaint of Frogger, and a few others I have yet to see. As the game is a point and click adventure there is no customization or RPG style elements aside from collecting various items and combining them in various ways to help you throughout your journey.

What truly makes this game unique is the mix of disturbing gore and story elements with the adorable, storybook artstyle. The result is a beautiful game with tons of little details that require a couple playthroughs or so to understand everything. However once clues are pieced together you'll find yourself going Ah-hah!" and even getting surprised at some of the twists and turns.

Then there's the truly disturbing parts; the blood

Did you like Silent Hill 2?

Do you like fetch quests and point & click adventure games?

No? Then ♥♥♥♥ off, 'cause you're gonna hate this game. If you love that stuff, then this is your game of the year right here. And that's your tl;dr.

For those of you that are still here, this game is amazing and more than worth the seemingly hefty fifteen dollar asking price. I mention Silent Hill 2 for a reason, because this game evokes that same concept of partaking in a macabre adventure in an effort to overcome grief and some other spoiler-y emotions, and come to some sense of self-realization. Without spoiling, this is a game where you need to take everything you see with a grain of salt, because it deals very heavily with methaporical imagery and situations.

The writing, probably the cornerstone of every adventure game, is actually childisly simple and frank, but in an endearing way rather than the 'the writer looks up to George Lucas as a role model' kind of way. It's certainly appropriate, considering you're playing a ten-year old girl. Despite being dialogue-heavy, this is one of those cases where there's a lot of showing rather than telling, i.e. the good way to do video game story-telling. To get a firm grasp of the plot. paying attention to the visuals and environment is just as important as actually reading what characters are saying. None of this is to say the characters are poorly written and realized, though; Fran's interactions with her kitty and various other people are charming enough that you'll very quickly warm up to both her and whoever she's talking too.

But to go back to how this game compares to Silent Hill 2, what's the other fundamental pillar of an adventure game? Yeah, get ready for some ♥♥♥♥ing fetch quests. This isn't one of those 'baby's first point-and-click' games that Telltale likes to make so much, where your key to progression is in plain sight and practically begging you to pick it up. Oh no, get ready to wear out you left mouse button as you furiously pound on every object in the game that could conceivably cough up some sort of item.

It's admittedly almost parodic how much characters refuse to help you unless you give them some dumb ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t; the game is hardly subversive in the gameplay department. There's no 'moon logic' at work here, though, as it's never ambigious as to what you're fetching or how you can get it. This might actually let some veteran adventure gamers down, because your tasks are never particularly difficult to fulfill. Still, there's something to be said for how insane some of the fetching can get. There's one point in the game where you need to do four fetch quests in order to complete another fetch quest, which turns out to be the key for another fetch quest. The layers of fetch quest in this portion of the game are insane, and definitely the low point of the experience. Still, it's in the middle, and leads to some of the best portions of the story.

And to wrap up some miscellanious stuff, the artwork is so good that it can easily portray both the grotesque and the cute stuff without either looking too out of place in the game. The art actually reminds me a lot of Broken Age, and as an aside, holy ♥♥♥♥ is this the level of imagination and thematic intelligence that Double Fine should've been aiming for with those fat stacks of Kickstarter money, instead of the garbage they actually put out. The music is pretty good for what it is, which is setting up the mood and atmosphere. The sound design is amazing as well, and like Silent Hill 2 (you probably should be taking shots at this point), highlights just how important good sound design can be for games like this. Every drip of water, every creak, every distant moan, and every naseuating squish helps build tension in all the right places.

Oh, and in case you couldn't tell from the screenshots, trailer, or my review, this game isn't for the faint of heart. Don't let the age of the protagonist fool you: there is some seriously ♥♥♥♥ed up ♥♥♥♥ here, and I'm not just talking about gore. That's ♥♥♥♥♥ stuff. I won't spill any details, but by Chapter 2 Part II you'll know exactly what I mean.

All this to say, it's a phenomenal game concerned with the heart-breaking exploration of the mind of a broken little girl, but it juxtaposes the gloom and doom with some levity and hope. It's only really hampered with an overreliance on fetch quests, but that's hardly a detriment to people who like this sort of game. If it weren't for the Witcher 3, this would easily be my Game of the Year; as is, it certainly is the Best Indie of the year, and the best in a long time as well.

Quick first line summary:  I really enjoyed this game, and would recommend it with very little hesitation.

Gameplay
It’s a point and click adventure game.  So you gather items from the various screens you can access and you use those items on characters or objects in the area to get access to more screens where you do more of the same.  This is pretty standard fare, so unless you have never played one before you already know how this works.  I will say that the puzzles are very logical for this sort of game, and the few times I got stuck it was entirely because of my own mistakes.

Visual Style
The visual look of the game is delightful.  I loved all the character art, and the locations were convincing and immersive.  If you are turned off by gore and upsetting imagery you might want to give this one a miss.  I found that the cartoony look offset the violence depicted, so it didn’t bother me, but I know I would advise my mother to stick to more light hearted stuff.  I did really like the spookiness of it all, and the odd moment where they decided to depict something particularly grotesque kept me always waiting for what would come next.

Story
Point and click adventure games seem to be the place to go for story these days.  Fran Bow’s story kept me strung along for the entire ride.  I liked what they did with some characters, the surprises they dropped here and there.  There wasn’t really any plot twists or sudden shifts of character that just came out of the blue and left me disbelieving.  Everything could, and was, explained with context and perspective to make sense.  Having said all that, there is one aspect of the story that I would need to say is this games weakest point, and unfortunately that is the ending.  I’m not going to spoil anything specifically, but if you want to experience the game completely blind, you might as well skip the next paragraph.

For the entire game there was one massive looming adversary with infrequent hints of shadow players in the wings.  When the final chapters rolled around that adversary just disappeared and was replaced with new ones at the last minute who were just as quickly bumped off in the most contrived way possible and then the game ended.  Just like that.  After all the build-up, all the hidden hints, all the vague clues to various possible twists and various possible conclusions, and all the uncertainty about how it could possibly work out well in the end, all the loose ends are just gathered up all at once and tied into one big deus ex machina bow.

Final Word
My final word on it echoes my first words.  I do highly recommend this game.  It has a few flaws, but it is an entrant in my library that I’m happy to have there.  It does make me want to check out other things this developer brings to the table.

A fantastic game set within a world that fluxes from whimsical to frightening and by the end manages to walk the line in between. Fran Bow's universe overall is surprisingly well-developed and very obviously is made of the stuff of both dreams and nightmares, as well as of real world horrors like child abuse, self-harm, pedophilia, and the very real inhumane experiments performed on patients locked within mental institutions. Along with the setting, its layers of multiple realities make for a fun game mechanic that nicely complements the exploratory elements of a point-and-click.

The writers did an amazing job of portraying Fran as a realistic child - earnest, naive, curious, and above all, resilient. She looks into the eyes of creatures that would make most adults turn and run, and she smiles and says hello because she has not yet been conditioned to fear such things. This makes her the perfect person with which to explore the setting and story of Fran Bow.

Speaking of, the game's story manages to be compelling and unexpected through all five of its chapters, introducing you to twisted authority figures and unexpected allies. Fran Bow plays with your trust, both with Fran's relationships with other characters and with its major themes: What is real and what isn't? Who is good and who is evil? (The answer is often not what you would traditionally expect.)

Yet instead of leaving players to question the ambiguous sanity and morals of the protagonist, as many psychological horror pieces do, it paints a picture of a child whose brain does not work like others' and yet is still kind and pure. Unlike others in its genre, Fran Bow is never an indictment of the mentally disordered. The monsters in the story are not Fran - they are the people trying to hurt her because of what she can see. Instead, Fran is the hero, her own hero. That is an important and powerful message, one that needs to be told more often.

The most noticeable weak point of the game for me was a few rather unintuitive puzzles. I consulted some walkthroughs and occassionally found myself wondering how on Earth a player was supposed to figure out a particular solution on their own without wildly trying to combine every object in their inventory with every part of the environment. This is something a lot of point-and-click games struggle with, Fran Bow being no different. Still, it wasn't as bad as, say, some of the later Myst games.

Mechanics wise, I didn't appreciate having to guess where my game had last auto-saved. With puzzle games, it's especially important not to lose progress and risk having to solve a complex puzzle all over again. I ended up playing to the end of chapters before quitting, just to be safe.

I will say that the soundtrack was underwhelming as well. The only place where I really noticed it was in the Ultrareality reception area because the casual elevator music really sold the humor of such an odd stop along the storyline. Because of this, I did find myself wishing the game were voice-acted so I would have something interesting to listen to, but I understand that budget limitations would make that an unreasonable request.

Fran Bow's art is beautiful, with a gothic style that lends itself well to both the cute and the terrifying. I'm incredibly disappointed that my Steam screenshot function didn't seem to be working during playthrough.

Final note: The black cat in the game is pure of heart and does not die. I want to personally thank the developers for that. The good black cat fits nicely with the subversion of the crazy little girl trope, and the fact that Fran got to be with Mr. Midnight and her other friends in the end made for exactly the kind of happy ending I believe most players would wish for her.
Out of fear of revealing ANY spoilers, I will simply say Fran Bow is 100% worth the purchase and I highly recommend it to anyone who likes a good story and a unique theme/art style.
